questions.question: Why is niching important for practice success?
options: It helps you stand out, attract ideal clients, and charge premium prices
It reduces the number of people you can help
It's not important - generalists are more successful
questions.explanation: Niching helps you stand out as the go-to expert in your area, attract ideal clients specifically looking for your expertise, charge premium prices, and create targeted marketing that resonates deeply.

questions.question: What should be included in a comprehensive client consultation?
options: Chief complaint, symptom timeline, medical history, medications, lifestyle, and gut-specific questions
questions.explanation: A comprehensive consultation includes chief complaint, symptom timeline, medical history, medications/supplements, family history, lifestyle factors, and gut-specific questions (bowel habits, bloating, food reactions, antibiotic history).

questions.question: Why is value-based pricing better than hourly rates?
options: Clients pay for transformation and outcomes, not hours, and it attracts more committed clients
questions.explanation: Trading time for money limits income potential. Clients want results and transformation, not hours. Value-based pricing focuses on outcomes delivered and premium pricing attracts more committed clients.

questions.question: What is the 80/20 rule for social media content?
questions.explanation: 80% of content should be educational and value-driven, 20% promotional. This builds trust and positions you as an expert before asking for anything. Too much promotion drives people away.

questions.question: What is a lead magnet?
options: A free resource offered in exchange for an email address to build your list
questions.explanation: A lead magnet is a free resource (guide, quiz, checklist) offered in exchange for an email address. It builds your list, demonstrates expertise, attracts ideal clients, and starts relationships before they become paying clients.

questions.question: What should be included in client agreements?
options: Informed consent, scope statement, confidentiality, cancellation policy, payment terms, and refund policy
questions.explanation: Client agreements should include informed consent, scope statement (not replacing medical care), confidentiality terms, cancellation policy, payment terms, and refund policy. These protect both parties.

questions.question: When should you refer a client to another provider?
options: Red flag symptoms, suspected serious conditions, need for prescriptions, mental health concerns, or no progress
questions.explanation: Refer when there are red flag symptoms, suspected serious conditions, need for prescription medications, mental health concerns beyond your training, or no progress after reasonable intervention. When in doubt, refer out.

questions.question: What are the core systems every practice needs?
options: Scheduling, intake, payment, communication, records, and follow-up systems
questions.explanation: Core systems include scheduling (online booking), intake (digital forms), payment (automated invoicing), communication (secure messaging), records (organized files), and follow-up (automated reminders).

questions.question: How should you track client outcomes?
options: Don't track - just trust client reports
Use standardized questionnaires, before/after labs, quality of life measures, and satisfaction surveys
Just ask if they feel better
questions.explanation: Track outcomes with standardized symptom questionnaires at start and end, before/after lab testing, quality of life measures (energy, sleep, mood), goal achievement assessment, and client satisfaction feedback.

questions.question: When is the best time to ask for referrals?
options: When clients are getting results and feeling good about their progress
Only at the end of the program
Never ask - wait for them to offer
questions.explanation: Ask for referrals when clients are getting results and feeling good about their progress. This is when they're most enthusiastic and likely to share. Don't wait until the endâ€”capture the momentum when it's high.
